V5.CHILE: Conventional, undramatic weather across the country. Quality is excellent across most varieties and regions.
V5.ALSACE: Very difficult in view of the high temperatures. Acidity levels were so low that growers were, for once, allowed to add acid, though few of them really got the hang of it. Early maturing wines.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Extreme(ly sweet) but not particularly botrytised wines from this extreme(ly hot, dry) growing season.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: A small proportion of monumental wines from old vines were produced this heatwave year, but generally the frail Pinot Noir grape suffered raisining and made some very unusual wines indeed, some of which provide good, luscious drinking at about five years old but dry tannins are expected to make their presence increasingly felt.
V5.CHAMPAGNE: Spring frosts followed by one of the hottest summers on record led to small volumes and typically very ripe wines of middling quality. Some fine Pinot Noir dominant blends.
V5.LOIRE VALLEY: A famously atypical vintage across Europe, which resulted in a great harvest in the Loire. Muscadet is rich and full, but with good natural balance. Cabernet Franc reached full ripeness with ease, giving particularly expressive fruit character. Chenin Blanc was similarly generous, although there was less botrytis than normal. Perhaps the only casualty was Sauvignon Blanc, which was routinely reaching 14% alcohol, resulting in overripe wines without their usual delicacy.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Excessive heat had fewer ill effects in this hot region than in the (usually) more temperate climes of Bordeaux and Burgundy. But the wines tend to be low in tannin and high in acid and only the best have the balance to last.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Exceptional heatwave resulted in many raisined grapes and uncomfortably dry tannins. A handful of stunning wines for the long term but most are probably best drunk while the bloom of youth can distract from that dryness.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Acid levels were dangerously low in the heatwave. For very early drinking except for the very finest.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: A very difficult year with exceptionally low levels of acid, some of them made from grapes that shrivelled rather than ripened. Curious.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: The heatwave resulted in some very strange musts with such low acids and such high sugars than some fermentations got stuck, resulting in sweetish wines. Definitely not for the long term.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Some exceptional heatwave wines with enormous concentration and, we hope, a long and glorious life ahead.
V5.GERMANY: Uncomfortably hot year for the Riesling vine, and even more of an assault on varieties such as Grauburgunder and Weissburgunder with their naturally lower acid levels. But some exceptional wines were made at the top of the tree.
V5.PIEMONTE: As elsewhere, the heatwave shrivelled grapes and resulted in some unbalanced musts although the oldest vines in Barolo and Barbaresco managed to withstand the weather and yield some exceptional wines.
V5.TUSCANY: Very difficult heatwave conditions were felt in all but the highest vineyards of Chianti Classico. Wines generally pretty unbalanced.
V5.NEW ZEALAND: Spring frosts reduced yield in many areas, producing 35% less fruit than in 2002. Quality is considered good albeit not stellar.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Some great vintage ports, not harmed by the hot summer and helped by newfound alternative techniques to foot treading.
V5.SOUTH AFRICA: Temperatures several degrees below the average, with the best results coming from the earlier ripening varieties.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Small, early, drought-plagued harvest of often unbalanced wines.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Rushed vintage as everything ripened at the same time after heat spikes followed rain and a cool May. Reduced crop.

V5.ARGENTINA: Hotter than average, giving ripe, round tannin with full flavour ripeness.
V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Poor weather at flowering reduced yields considerably and was followed by an unusually cool summer and a late harvest leading to some high-quality wines. Inland irrigated regions benefited most obviously from this prolonged growing season.
V5.CHILE: Extensive rain and rot damage in the south, but was dry and healthy in the north, albeit with yields up to 25% below the norm.
V5.ALSACE: Fine weather at flowering followed an exceptionally cold winter so crop-thinning was necessary for high quality. The summer was much better than in most of France but rain in early October threatened the health of some grapes.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Vineyards near the rivers were blessed with botrytis. Small crop.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Good vintage. Summer was not especially hot, though it was reasonably dry. Sugar levels were boosted in September but some grapes were adversely affected by scattered rains then. Sugar levels were quite respectable in the end and most wines showed their charms at an early stage.
V5.CHAMPAGNE: A magnificent vintage for champagne with near-perfect growing conditions, capped by fine dry weather at harvest. Ageworthy wines with plush fruit held in check by keen acidity.
V5.LOIRE VALLEY: A successful if somewhat cool year, characterised by classic balance and structure for all varieties. The opposite in style to the opulent
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: So wet that there was flood damage just before harvest. Much downgrading of fruit into humbler bottlings than usual.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Smallish crop dogged by an uneven flowering and a grey, humid summer which meant uneven ripeness in far-from-uniformly healthy grapes. Growers concentrated on the rescue effect of pretty fine weather from 9 September. The wines are correct and, in a 21st-century context, are not expensive, but they may not last all that long.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Small crop of concentrated, fragrant wines.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Good quality and quantity.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Extremely variable. An unusually grey summer ended with disastrous floods in the Gard _département _in the far east of the region although many growers in the hills managed to make good wine.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Poor weather at flowering dramatically reduced the potential crop and paved the way for a thoroughly horrid summer resulting in rotten, unripe grapes. Some growers declassified a large proportion of them although the odd late-picked bottling may surprise. Reds should have been drunk. Good white wines though.
V5.GERMANY: German growers were in general much happier than their French counterparts throughout the summer but many were finally caught out by rain before harvest in October which meant that very few wines above Auslese quality resulted and the rather soft wines have aged relatively rapidly.
V5.PIEMONTE: Piemonte's run of good to great vintages was finally broken with disastrous hail in parts of Barolo, rot, unripeness and unusually cool weather. The thin-skinned Barbera suffered most in this small vintage.
V5.TUSCANY: Exceptionally wet summer resulted in rotten grapes, many of which failed to reach full ripeness. A real _annus horribilis._
V5.NEW ZEALAND: Warm weather that was good for Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, but less beneficial to Sauvignon Blanc.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: The usual very dry summer was followed by an unusually wet September which compromised both the health and ripeness of those grapes that were picked. A most unusual harvest and extremely unlikely to produce vintage port.
V5.SOUTH AFRICA: Rain in abundance, leading to plentiful rot. Not a good vintage.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Exceptionally cold winter and spring was followed by nasty wet weather during summer - disastrous for both quality and quantity. Rain persisted even during harvest. Truly a severe test for both regions.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Summer started cool and continued very dry - quite exceptionally dry - so that the ripening process simply stopped and growers had to bite their nails through September waiting for anything like ideal ripeness. As in Europe, a difficult vintage, but for very different reasons.

V5.ARGENTINA: Unremarkable wines, with rain leading to dilution in many examples.
V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: A vintage that rewarded the quality-conscious. A usefully wet start to the growing season was followed by prolonged very hot, dry weather, broken by rain just before harvest in March. Some grapes suffered sunburn but lower-yielding vineyards produced true quality.
V5.CHILE: A hot, dry summer with making concentrated reds, especially Cabernet Sauvignon and Carmenère.
V5.ALSACE: Flowering was extended by low temperatures. Late autumn warmth made up somewhat for a coolish summer and wet September, which robbed the region of a great vintage but there are some excellent wines drinking well now.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: The rain that spoilt the reds encouraged botrytis to such an extent that this is a truly magnificent, long-term vintage, helped by a greater degree of selection and cellar expertise than ever before. Perhaps the greatest Sauternes vintage in modern times.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Wet summer with some heat spikes. As for red bordeaux from this vintage, a gentle hand was needed in the winery to retain delicacy and not emphasize the already notable tannins. Quite varied quality. Wines from low-yielding grapes will provide exciting long-term drinking but others are gawky. August hail in Volnay.
V5.CHAMPAGNE: A generally poor vintage characterised by rot and underripeness thanks to a wet and gloomy September.
V5.LOIRE VALLEY: Good for Muscadet, but bad for Sancerre and Pouilly-Fumé where late rain caused rot. Anjou enjoyed fine, late summer warmth allowing the production of particularly good sweet wines.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Lauded vintage, the result of a very hot, dry summer. An unusually prolonged _mistral_ at the end of August resulted in thick-skinned berries and accentuated tannins. Later harvesting resulted in better balanced wines - especially in higher-yielding vineyards - but acid levels are dangerously low in some cases. There should be some very long-lived top wines however.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Extremely varied, large crop which depended on crop-thinning and extremely careful selection to produce exceptional wines. Hot August was followed by dangerously wet September, which sometimes resulted in dilute Merlots and tart Cabernets. Some good value to be found here, and with time the 2001s showed better and better - especially on the right bank where it can be superior to 2000.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: The low temperatures of September helped maintain freshness and produced well-etched, fruity flavours with good acidity.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Erratic weather produced some rot but also some surprisingly good white wines, if not for the long term, as well as some rather thin, disappointing ones. A variable vintage that rewarded those who limited yields. Devastating hail in parts of the Côte Chalonnaise.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Summer was so hot and dry that some vines shut down and stopped ripening. Rain in September was a relief for those who picked after it although the wines picked too early may be uncomfortably tough. White wines are particularly concentrated.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: One of the most successful regions in France in 2001. Almost as good as 1999 if more elegant and less concentrated than 2000.Very respectable levels of ripeness and good acidity and ripe tannins to support them.
V5.GERMANY: A very great, long-term vintage with remarkable levels of both grape ripeness (thanks to a wonderful Indian summer) and acidity (thanks to a nerve-wrackingly wet but cool September). A high proportion of botrytised sweet wines were made - in fact there was such a shortage of basic QbA wine that considerable amounts were declassified to satisfy market demand.
V5.PIEMONTE: Excellent quality (and quantity) from an early vintage slightly more in the voluptuous mould of 1999 and 1997 than particularly long-term. No shortage of ripeness or structure, but an occasional shortage of acidity.
V5.TUSCANY: Smallish crop thanks to April frosts. June and July were dry but August and especially September were quite wet with rain threatening vine health as harvest time approached.
V5.NEW ZEALAND: Exceptional quality on the south island, but was lighter in style on the north island.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Some very good vintage port. Exceptionally wet winter - an unprecedented five months of rain - was followed by early budburst slowed by a cool spring. The crop was reduced by a heatwave in June but conditions were favourable throughout the rest of the summer. Useful quantity with good not great quality.
V5.SOUTH AFRICA: Continued the run of hot vintages, and produced a very small harvest of concentrated reds. Tannins were generally softer than in 2000.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Smaller-than-usual crop because of spring frosts but distinctly superior quality accentuated in some cases by further deliberate crop thinning. Some very fine wines.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: A respite for growers plagued by unusual conditions in both 2000 and 2002 with most varieties ripening evenly when expected, although some Cabernet vines shut down in August. A coolish September was a boon.

V5.ARGENTINA: A cool vintage, leaving the wines with high acid and fresh fruit.
V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Very challenging vintage conditions which included poor flowering, hail, exceptional heat in summer and rain during harvest. There were problems with colour stability. Small crop.
V5.ALSACE: An exceptional vintage in every sense with a very early flowering and a very favourable growing season. A little rot of all sorts developed at the end of August and rains in October were sometimes heavy but good quantities of excellent wines, including late harvest styles, were produced.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Some pretty, bumptious wines for relatively short-term drinking but there was too much rain after the red wine harvest for the development of botrytis.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: A difficult vintage for growers, with rain and rot during harvest. Rather soft, easy wines that were more successful in the Côte de Nuits than in much of the Côte de Beaune. Useful early drinking but showing signs of losing fruit by 2008.
V5.CHAMPAGNE: Hail, rainstorms, unseasonable cold and mildew made for a testing growing season, but fine conditions in August and September redeemed the vintage. High quality wines for short-term drinking.
V5.LOIRE VALLEY: Despite a wet July, quality turned out very well for dry whites and reds. Yields were marginally below average, and there was insufficient ripeness to create any moelleux styles.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Conditions were excellent until quite heavy rains arrived on 19 September. The results, especially from those who picked early and fast, are plump, approachable wines capable of giving great pleasure even if they will not be the longest-lasting.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Nature's benevolence coincided with the commercial imperative to have a good vintage in this numerically exceptional year. Great consistency and balance. The petits châteaux represented some of Bordeaux’s best value for many years though most are ready to drink or even starting to decline. The best wines should last well into their second or even third decades.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Summer was if anything too hot to produce nervy wines and most of these were best drunk young, although there are one or two great wines at the top of the tree.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Extremely ripe, sometimes too ripe, healthy grapes with fairly good acidity that were able to charm even in their youth. Especially good for Chablis and the Mâconnais.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Devastating floods in November 1999 damaged some vineyards, as did storms in June and July but the summer was warm and dry (though not excessively so) and was followed by a prolonged harvest with some very good quality wine. Lovely, round, supple wines with ripe tannins.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Good to very good if overshadowed by its predecessor. August was hot with heavy rain on 21 August. September enjoyed exceptionally fine weather allowing a particularly prolonged harvest. Both red and white wines are very charming.
V5.GERMANY: Very difficult vintage. Early optimism was finally dashed by September rains which severely compromised the health of the grapes. In many cases the earliest-picked grapes were the best because they were the least affected by rot. Early-picked Spätburgunders were relatively unscathed.
V5.PIEMONTE: Very good, partly thanks to a prolonged heatwave from mid-August to mid-September. Dolcettos were relatively simple but both Barbera and, especially, Nebbiolo were exceptional with excellent acidity as well as ripeness and great definition of flavour. For the long term.
V5.TUSCANY: Easy, ripe wines from a very hot, dry vintage which, unless vineyards were extremely well-managed, resulted in wines with a certain hollowness, though no shortage of alcohol.
V5.NEW ZEALAND: Much lower yields thanks to rot caused by rain. Marlborough was one of the best regions of the country.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Mild and exceptionally dry winter was followed by a wet spring which delayed the growth cycle. An unusually hot September gave the grapes a late boost just before harvest in benign conditions. The result of this, together with the introduction of new, mechanised alternatives to foot-treading in some houses, is a range of particularly luscious, ripe vintage ports.
V5.SOUTH AFRICA: The third hot year in a row. Whites were unimpressive, but reds were powerful and concentrated, with high tannic structure.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Record crop levels and extremely variable quality with exceptionally high summer temperatures and in many cases a lack of concentration. Some very good wines from Ribera del Duero though.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Long, late, 'European' vintage thanks to an unusually cool, wet summer. There were very real concerns that Cabernet Sauvignon would never ripen in some vineyards. A particularly good year for Pinot Noir and Chardonnay.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: The record crop was more the result of increased plantings than any natural phenomenon. Several years of drought conditions continued until summer, which was plagued by some storms which compromised vintage health. A cooler year than 1998.
V5.ALSACE: Rain plagued the growing season and brought rot and mildew. Fine weather began in mid August and continued for a month so that careful vignerons looked forward to good quality but hopes were dashed by yet more rain.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Those producers who used only the very rich, botrytised grapes picked first produced some exciting wines but quality is extremely variable as later-picked grapes suffered somewhat.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Exceptional quality and quantity. Powerful, charming and well balanced with great concentration and colour - particularly in the Côte de Beaune. The Côte de Nuits was hampered by a little more rain. Tannins and pigments achieved sumptuous ripeness. A vintage to drink young or old.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Rather more challenging vintage than 2000 for growers and wines with less obvious richness than 1998 for wine drinkers. Heavy rains plagued the harvest and quality is distinctly variable.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Good potential created almost exclusively by three weeks of sunshine from late August was diluted by rain at harvest time. Hail also devastated some St-Émilion vineyards in early September. A cool, humid start to the growing season led to excessive vegetation initially. Fairly early maturing wines with better potential on the left bank.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Some attractive, aromatic Sauvignon Blanc was harvested but the Sémillon fruit was often dilute.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Large crop ripened by fine weather in late August and early September. Generally slightly crisper than the 2000s and the best may last longer - if they are allowed to.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: An exceptionally dry winter was followed by heavy rainfall, and some hail in Roussillon, at the end of April. Wines are respectable but not as exciting as the vintages immediately before and after.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Exceptional quality. A sunny harvest saw good quantities of healthy grapes - a cause for real celebration in the northern Rhône. Quality is at least as good as 1998 (some compare it with 1947) and the quantity was much higher.
V5.GERMANY: Everything was going so well...until the rains which began on 20 September and continued throughout the harvest. Careful selection was needed and in some cases yields were too high for real quality. Acids were generally low but some delicious wines for relatively early drinking were made by the best producers.
V5.PIEMONTE: Very good quality yet again for Nebbiolo-based wines, and Dolcetto which was much more successful than the later-ripening Barbera. Voluptuous Barolo and Barbaresco recalls 1997.
V5.TUSCANY: Quite exceptionally good quality. A vintage not unlike 1997 but with arguably more finesse and less sheer mass. Warm summer led to an early harvest of healthy grapes.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: At the end of August growers were looking forward to a distinct improvement on 1998 but hopes were washed away by continuous rain in September, although the thick-skinned port grapes suffered much less than table wine grapes elsewhere in Portugal.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: April frost in Rioja delayed ripening of grapes that suffered thanks to summer rains. Better quality in Ribera del Duero, however, although harvest rain reduced acidity. Good quality but not quite as good as
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Very late, dry, cool growing season which depended crucially on ripeness being boosted by a late September heatwave. A late rush resulted in many varieties ripening simultaneously leading to a short, extremely pressurised harvest. Some luscious Cabernets were made as a result of the relatively new preoccupation with extended 'hang time'.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Was then a record crop from an early, frantic vintages despite drought conditions. Some fine reds.
V5.ALSACE: Early harvest of very ripe grapes with some botrytis.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Rather loose, early-drinking wines without strong botrytis influence.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Thick skins made for good colours but pretty tough and stolid wines in general.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Much garlanded vintage that struggled to live up to its reputation during its teenage years.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Very good on the right bank but a less starry performance in the Médoc, whose 1998s are a bit stolid, means that these wines, and their equally successful counterparts in Graves have tended to be overlooked.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Attractive wines with no shortage of ripeness.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Everything went wrong: frost, hail, powdery mildew. Respectable, considering.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Very good, small crop.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Very dry summer stressed the vines. Some tough wines for the long term.
V5.GERMANY: Despite a wet growing season the wines showed vibrant acidity and bright fruit. Eiswein was made in some quantity.
V5.PIEMONTE: More structure and potential than 1997 and some very fine, elegant wines.
V5.TUSCANY: Irregular vintage after another hot summer which stressed the vines.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Definitely not a year for vintage port.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Despite spring frosts, yields were still too high to ripen some grapes sufficiently in Ribera del Duero. Quantity was also Rioja’s strong suit.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: The cliffhanger vintage that was as late as 1997 was early. Wines tend to lack stuffing, although some Cabernets took on surprising charm after 10 years in bottle.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Vintage saved by a hot April with some fine Shiraz made, eventually, which should have a long life.
V5.ALSACE: Some really excellent wines. Early harvest of very ripe grapes plus some outstanding sweet, later picked wines.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Some very attractive, if not especially heavy, wines from the top producers. Ready to start drinking.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Charming, early-drinking wines – most should have been drunk by now.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Rather muddy flavours from well ripened grapes.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Far from dramatic and early developers, these wines were ludicrously overpriced initially but provided some easy drinking in the early years of this century. Few show any possibility of improvement.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Rather lacklustre without much depth or personality.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Charming wines for relatively early drinking.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Large crop, difficult season.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Early maturing, soft wines from an early harvest.
V5.GERMANY: Early, large crop of very attractive wines – generally clustered around Spätlese level of ripeness, although there are some lovely Mosel Auslesen.
V5.PIEMONTE: A hot growing season resulted in record ripeness levels but some worryingly low acidities.
V5.TUSCANY: Hot summer and very ripe grapes that produced wines that seemed unusually luscious at the time even if some could do with a little more freshness.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Some fine vintage ports. Early flowering was followed by a fairly cool, wet summer so the ports are more structured than the 1994s.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Rain at harvest. Not glorious.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Early, generous harvest of widely admired wines with all varieties ripening at once. To drink now.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: A big vintage at last, with sugars boosted by a late burst of heat.
V5.ALSACE: Solid but not desperately exciting wines.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Very slightly less successful than the 1997 vintage.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Remarkably high acidity has made its presence increasingly felt over the years in bottle. Some wines just too tart for comfort; others may eventually bloom.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Coolish, damp summer produced lighter-than-usual wines.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Some very fine, potentially long lived wines, especially in the Médoc, although robust tannin levels recall 1986s in many cases.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Like most French 1996 whites, vivacious, crisp wines.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: As with the reds, acidity is the keynote. The best-balanced are stunning but some are a bit meagre.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Large crop and a rainy summer which affected reds more than whites.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Solid, unexciting but ready and competently made.
V5.GERMANY: Attractive, lightish Mosels and southern wines with more stuffing. A very good year for Eiswein.
V5.PIEMONTE: Superb Barolo and Barbaresco for keeping.
V5.TUSCANY: Very varied year producing soft, early maturing wines that should have been drunk by now.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Not a year for vintage port but some fine single quinta wines were made.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Particularly successful in Ribera del Duero, where ripe, relatively friendly wines were made.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Small crop of relatively lightweight wines, most of which should probably have been drunk.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Inconveniently small crop but some good Shiraz and Rieslings, especially in Clare, where quantities were better than elsewhere
V5.ALSACE: Varied year in which those who picked low-yielding vineyards well after the rains made great Rieslings, some very ripe. Rot threatened everyday wines. Slightly reduced crop.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Best Sauternes vintage since 1990 - so probably initially overrated. The noble rot developed so rapidly that most of the grapes were picked by early October. Not the most complex vintage.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Reduced crop of initially rather austere wines which took on fat in bottle and can provide delicious drinking now.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Very good colour and really ripe, concentrated reds. Some producers claim it is better than 1990.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Hot, dry summer resulted in early harvest of healthy Merlot grapes. Relatively tannic Cabernet Sauvignon was picked after a week of mid-September rain. Generous crop levels, best in Pomerol and Pauillac.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Lots of body and flavour and structure thanks to the warm summer wherever grapes were picked before the mid-September rains.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Very small crop producing wines with real concentration.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Excellent ripeness and concentration in reds, especially in the hills.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Very promising vintage which is just starting to come round at the top end.
V5.GERMANY: An unusually warm summer was followed by a cold, wet late August and September so that the bulk of wine produced was rather ordinary, but the late, great Riesling showed its stuff in the Mosel after a very warm October.
V5.PIEMONTE: Hail-reduced crop of deep-coloured wines made from grapes which benefited from a sunny autumn. Probably a notch below 1989 and 1990.
V5.TUSCANY: Nail-bitingly late harvest saved by an unusually warm, dry October, although acids are still generally high.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Some real potential for vintage port.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Another frost-shrunk crop in Ribera del Duero, although the grapes were riper and probably better balanced than in 1994. Rioja's bodegas, on the other hand, were swollen by an enormous harvest of ripe, healthy grapes.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Yet another region in which a warm, dry autumn and late harvest saved the day after a difficult growing season. Reds, especially Zinfandels, may be even better than 1991. Small quantities pushed up prices, however.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Exceptionally dry but not too hot: the resulting wines are deep and structured, especially from the Barossa Valley.
V5.ALSACE: September rain, but impressive wines from those brave enough to pick late.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Grey rot in September, so choose the châteaux that could afford to be fussy.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: A year to highlight Burgundy's infamy for variability as too many let yields balloon after the rains.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Early harvesters were luckier, most picked in rain, so only average quality.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: The best year since 1990 (which is not saying that much). Nicely ripe but September rains were a problem again for less conscientious producers.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Potentially superb as fully ripe grapes were again gathered before the rains.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Generally better than the reds and certainly more consistent, especially the Mâconnais.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Probably France's most successful region: a small crop with real richness and concentration.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: All-too familiar autumn rains before the fruit could ripen.
V5.GERMANY: Horribly variable, but Riesling showed its class with superb quality from the good estates.
V5.PIEMONTE: Sugar and acid levels reasonable despite prolonged September rains. Not up to Tuscany’s performance.
V5.TUSCANY: At last a dry but cool harvest: rich and structured and certainly the best since 1990.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Potentially exceptional year for vintage port. Very rich but not overripe wines.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Quality isn't a problem but quantity is after spring frosts and summer drought. Some very nice wines indeed.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Generally compared to 1991, the slow ripening benefited the reds especially.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Ripening was slowed by an unusually cool and wet spell. A challenging year with the whites especially more variable than usual.
V5.ALSACE: A good year: ripe wines of weight and intensity.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Another pretty dreadful autumn, hardly anyone made interesting wine.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Underrated. Better than average: healthy grapes and well-coloured, fruity wines that have lasted and developed well.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: An unwelcome repeat of 1992's weather: diluted, easy-drinking wines.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Another wet harvest. Picked earlier, the right bank a better bet than the left.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Avoided the rains: generally good, soft and full, sometimes outstanding.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: A large, ripe harvest struck by rain, so concentration was a problem.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: After a wonderful summer this was an exciting vintage.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: A great summer then rain, hail and mildew, so light, soft wines are the rule.
V5.GERMANY: A nerve-racking year. Rain hit the early harvests but patient growers picked grapes with welcome botrytis. Some fine wines still showing well.
V5.PIEMONTE: Nebbiolo and Barbera didn't really ripen before it rained. May be similar to 1988.
V5.TUSCANY: Survived the rains better than Piemonte, concentration held up, but some picked unripe fruit.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: NA
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Heavy harvest rains again. Good but not great seems the rule.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Erratic growing conditions reduced eventual yields. A mixed bag.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Cool temperatures at harvest ensured balanced wines, exceptional from Clare Valley.
V5.ALSACE: Better than most French regions: ripe, soft and forward.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Endless rains ruined the crop. Many estates declassified altogether.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Rain at the wrong time again. Soft, tender wines to drink young.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Torrential harvest rains drowned the vineyards and the results are pretty dilute.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Light, fruity, simple wines that needed drinking early.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Clearly better than the reds, the best are intense and well-structured.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Balanced, elegant and refined: best from the Côte d’Or rather than Chablis.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Irregular quality inevitable after localised autumn downpours.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: Heavy September rains gave a mixed bag of early-drinking wines.
V5.GERMANY: Not bad, particularly in the Rhine. Estates had to control yields to overcome dilution from the rains and maintain balance.
V5.PIEMONTE: A large harvest, generally low on weight and power.
V5.TUSCANY: A big crop of rather light wines to drink young.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Taylor and Fonseca chose to declare this instead of 1991.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: This looked good until prolonged rains, which diluted the grapes and encouraged rot. Early maturing. Should have been drunk.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: Plenty of good reds and whites, with Merlot, then increasingly fashionable, a highlight.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Dry weather restricted yields, but the quality was generally fine for all varieties.
V5.ALSACE: A difficult year, rain hit the harvest and the wines are light and acidic.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: After the April frosts a tiny crop was eventually harvested, but not bad.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Grapes had ripened before it rained and some wines from the Côtes de Nuits are excellent. Not to be overlooked.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: The Grenache failed at flowering and harvest time was uninspiring. Best forgotten.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: The start of Bordeaux's run of bad luck. Spring frosts decimated the right bank, but the top Médocs are not bad.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: A difficult year, rather light and most are just too dilute to be interesting.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Rain reduced acidity and concentration, some were delightful but many were dilute.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: A really outstanding year of rich, dense and big-structured wines, especially in Roussillon.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: A good vintage, superb in Côte-Rôtie: fragrant, forward and charming.
V5.GERMANY: Ripe, crisp, even slightly austere wines, just the stuff for Kabinetts!
V5.PIEMONTE: A smallish crop of light to mid-weight early-drinking wines.
V5.TUSCANY: Endless harvest rains so the best were no more than pleasant.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: Great potential, very rich with considerable structure. A long-term vintage.
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: An excellent year in Spain, only a small crop but impressive weight and structure.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: A long growing season reflected in unusually fragrant, complex wines, with Zinfandel strong.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: Ideal weather: enough water and moderate temperatures. An excellent year in all regions.
V5.ALSACE: A third wonderful year of classic, powerful, long-lived wines; the best still going strong.
V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Massive rich wines that presently seem a shade less complex than 1989 and, especially, 1988.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: A great success: rich and fragrant. The top vineyards made majestic wines but some lesser wines lacked lusciousness.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Exceptionally sumptous, powerful and heady wines with fairly low acidity. Only the finest survive.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Second scorching year in a row. Very ripe, alluring wines at all levels, many outstanding. The vintage character of velvety texture and luscious, almost overripe fruit is one of the easiest to spot and tends to impose itself over any geographical characteristics.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Mostly richer, fuller and more complex than 1989, but not very long-lived.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: Very ripe but yields were just too high for profound wines. Chablis best.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: Generous weather gave excellent wines that were fruity and delicious.
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: The heatwave slowed ripening. Côte-Rôtie suffered but the Hermitage hill produced some monster wines destined for a very long life.
V5.GERMANY: Europe's wonder year: a perfect autumn with plenty of late-picked sweet wines after a botrytis bonanza.
V5.PIEMONTE: With colossal power and big aromas these are very exciting wines which have repaid extended bottle age.
V5.TUSCANY: A hot year and low yields, the ingredients for really good wines, especially in Montalcino.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: NA
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Another large and fine quality crop in all areas.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: A modest-sized crop, the top Cabernets and Chardonnays rivalled 1985.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: NA

V5.BORDEAUX - SWEET: Huge, almost corpulent wines that are dramatic and exciting.
V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Nearly up to 1990, if not as intense. Some real charmers.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Fabulously concentrated with perhaps more backbone than 1990.
V5.BORDEAUX - RED: Seemed an unusually hot summer at the time, producing a huge crop of rich, opulent, expensive wines, drinking astonishingly well young. Some very good right bank wines indeed. And an exceptional year for Haut-Brion.
V5.BORDEAUX - WHITE: Picked too soon, generally light and not a patch on the reds except for Laville-Haut-Brion and Haut-Brion.
V5.BURGUNDY - WHITE: A medium-sized crop produced spectacularly rich and horribly expensive wines.
V5.LANGUEDOC-ROUSSILLON: NA
V5.NORTHERN RHÔNE: A drought year, irregular in Cornas, otherwise rich and opulent.
V5.GERMANY: A phenomenal harvest. The late-harvested Rieslings show profound complexity. Probably best in the Mosel.
V5.PIEMONTE: A superb, healthy crop. Top Barolos are thrilling and repay the wait.
V5.TUSCANY: Distinctly inferior to Piemonte. Light if not watery, so best to avoid.
V5.PORT AND THE DOURO: NA
V5.RIOJA AND RIBERA DEL DUERO: Plenty of rich and charming wines from both regions.
V5.NORTHERN CALIFORNIA: After autumn rains, poorly drained sites suffered, and many picked too early. Variable, especially the whites.

V5.SOUTH AUSTRALIA: NA

V5.BURGUNDY - RED: Tough and unusually backward, most are densely concentrated and the best repaid 20 years’ wait.
V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Good in all areas: full bodied and with firm tannins, often termed 'classic'.

V5.SOUTHERN RHÔNE: Charming and ripe, even opulent, and now quite soft.
